html:
Bieber will serve as Rhode’s chief creative officer and head of innovation, as well as a strategic adviser for both companies.

Hailey Bieber, co-founder of Rhode. Photo: Getty Images

Low-cost makeup and skincare giant E.l.f. Beauty is acquiring Hailey Bieber’s skin-care brand Rhode in a deal worth $1 billion. According to a press release, this “powerhouse alliance” is “built on both brands’ shared focus on disruption and product innovation.”

“From day one, my vision for Rhode has been to make essential skin care and hybrid makeup you can use every day,” said Bieber, who made Inc.’s 2024 Female Founders list, in the press release. “Just three years into this journey, our partnership with E.l.f. Beauty marks an incredible opportunity to elevate and accelerate our ability to reach more of our community with even more innovative products and widen our distribution globally.”

The deal includes $600 million in cash, $200 million in “newly issued shares of E.l.f. Beauty common stock issued to existing equity holders of Rhode,” and the potential to earn an additional $200 million based on Rhode’s growth over the next three years after closing, per the press release. The companies expect to close in Q2 of 2026.

Bieber founded Rhode in 2022 along with married couple Michael D. Ratner, who serves as the brand’s co-executive chairman, and Lauren Ratner, who serves as its president and chief brand officer. All three co-founders will “continue to lead the brand” along with CEO Nick Vlahos, according to the press release. Bieber’s role, in fact, will expand. She’ll serve as Rhode’s chief creative officer and head of innovation, and “act as a strategic advisor to the combined companies,” per the press release.

Over the past year, Rhode says it has doubled its consumer base, driven $212 million in net sales, and grown its earned media value by 367 percent. The Los Angeles-based company will also soon launch its first physical in-store partnership with Sephora stores across North America and the U.K.

The deal “further diversifies our portfolio with a fast-growing brand that makes the best of prestige accessible,” E.l.f. CEO and chairman Tarang Amin said in the press release.

The beauty giant, founded in 2004, says that according to the latest data from audience measurement company Nielsen, it’s the No. 1 U.S. cosmetic brand in units and No. 2 in dollar share. Over the past five years, E.l.f. has prioritized expanding its skin-care offerings, launching an in-house skin-care brand in 2020 and acquiring natural skin-care brand Naturium for $355 million in 2023. 

Just last week, E.l.f. made waves by announcing it would raise prices by $1 this fall due to tariffs and inflation.
